Overview

In this section, we'll look at some of the properties of \(\mathbb{R}^n\) vector spaces.
In particular, we'll look at bases, linear independence, span, dimension, and how they all relate.
 We'll also briefly talk about vector subspaces.

Overview

Since the highlight of this section is on vector bases, we'll spend the most time explaining these.
Recall from section #2, we can write a vector as a sum of its components.
 \( \begin{bmatrix}4 \\ -1\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}4 \\ 0\end{bmatrix} + \begin{bmatrix}0 \\ -1\end{bmatrix} \)
Let's build on this by breaking these components down into a scalar value and vector which is all zeros except for a value which is a 1.
 \( \begin{bmatrix}4 \\ -1\end{bmatrix} = 4\begin{bmatrix}1 \\ 0\end{bmatrix} - 1\begin{bmatrix}0 \\ 1\end{bmatrix} \)

This works for any vector in \(\mathbb{R}^n\) space:

$$ \begin{bmatrix}2.5 \\ 5\end{bmatrix} = 2.5\begin{bmatrix}1 \\ 0\end{bmatrix} - 5\begin{bmatrix}0 \\ 1\end{bmatrix} $$

$$ \begin{bmatrix}-2 \\ 6 \\ 5\end{bmatrix} = -2\begin{bmatrix}1 \\ 0 \\ 0\end{bmatrix} + 6\begin{bmatrix}0 \\ 1 \\ 0\end{bmatrix} + 5\begin{bmatrix}0 \\ 0 \\ 1\end{bmatrix} $$

Standard Basis

These 'all zeros except a one' vectors are part of the standard basis. Elements of a basis are called basis vector
We can think of these basis vectors as the base units of a vector space. Every other vector in the vector space can be produced using them.
Each standard basis vector is a normalized vector facing in the positive direction of a coordinate axis.
 For 2-3 dimensions, we represent these standard basis vectors with the variables \(\hat{i}\), \(\hat{j}\), and \(\hat{k}\).
